Headline: CEO at Stealth Mode Startup
Comment:
Interesting topic here â€” and the time is right to discuss it before calmness turns into chaos.
Here's my take:
Valuation wasnâ€™t born in the founderâ€™s pitch deck, yet itâ€™s become the default yardstick for startups â€” often the first question asked, even before the product demo is over.
This obsession didnâ€™t start with founders. It took hold when big consulting firms and investment banks pushed â€œvaluation-led growthâ€ as the norm. Useful for M&A and IPO prep, but that mindset spilled into the early-stage world.
Founders trying to solve real problems were pushed to tell a â€œvaluation storyâ€ instead of a value creation one. And when valuation becomes the goal, it distorts priorities â€” growth at all costs, inflated forecasts, premature scaling.
Itâ€™s time to stop placing all the blame on founders. The narrative was shaped by those who benefited most from valuations on paper.
Valuation has its place. But the real scoreboard? Revenue, Retention, and Relevance.

Headline: CEO @ [Coming Soon] | Building Ecosystems, Not Just Startups | Designing Growth Engines Across Markets, Capital & People
Comment:
ValuationÂ isÂ a milestone; if youÂ earnedÂ it.
Not with decks, dreams, and decibels; but withÂ distribution, data, and demand.
You say $2M at $30M post is irresponsible. I say it's irresponsibleÂ only ifÂ your company was all bark and no bite.
But if youâ€™ve got the market by its throat,
If you know how toÂ create the narrative and own the outcome,
ThenÂ valuation is your playground; and you better play big.
The future doesnâ€™t belong to those who â€œprice for where they are.â€
It belongs to those whoÂ price for where the market is going; and thenÂ drag reality to match it.
Stop training founders to beÂ "reasonable."
The next unicorns wonâ€™t come from caution.
Theyâ€™ll come fromÂ clarity,Â conviction, and the courage to bet on themselvesÂ beforeÂ anyone else sees it.
So yeah; valuation is a responsibility.
But itâ€™s also a weapon.
Use it like one.
